TEXT: CARDINAL . NORP The applicant , PERSON , is a NORP and NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in GPE ( GPE ) . He was represented before the ORG by PERSON and PERSON , lawyers practising in GPE , and Lord GPE of LOC . ORG ( “ the Government ” ) were represented by their Agent , Mr PERSON , from ORG .
CARDINAL . NORP The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .
CARDINAL . NORP The applicant is the son of ORG , the founder of ORG , who conducted “ Baťa , a.s . ve GPE , a substantial enterprise in former GPE ( hereinafter “ the company ” ) .

CARDINAL . According to the applicant , on the death of his father in DATE , he and his mother inherited PERCENT and PERCENT respectively of the company 's shares . According to the Government , ownership of the shares did not pass to the applicant upon his father 's death . They refer to the agreement concluded between the applicant 's father and his step - uncle , PERSON , under which the shares had been sold by the former to the latter . This was confirmed by his father 's last will as interpreted by ORG ( okresní soud ) in inheritance proceedings , concluded on DATE , the outcome of which was contested neither by the applicant nor his mother .

CARDINAL . Shortly before the beginning of the Second World War , the applicant moved to GPE . In DATE he acquired NORP citizenship . In DATE the applicant 's mother died and the applicant , together with a certain PERSON , were granted administration of her estate . The latter died on DATE and the applicant became the sole executor of his mother 's estate .

CARDINAL . On DATE the then President of GPE issued Decree no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL on ORG and ORG ( dekret prezidenta republiky o znárodnění dolů a některých průmyslových podniků ) ( hereinafter “ the Decree ” ) .

CARDINAL . Pursuant to LAW ) , ( CARDINAL ) , ( CARDINAL ) and ( CARDINAL ) of the Decree , metalworking factories which had CARDINAL employees , certain chemical factories , enterprises producing tyres and synthetic rubber , knitting industry factories which had CARDINAL employees and factories producing hides which had CARDINAL employees were nationalised as from that date . ORG was authorised to declare , with reference to LAW , which companies were to be nationalised .
CARDINAL . By ordinances ( vyhlášky ) nos . CARDINAL and CARDINAL of DATE , published in ORG , the former Minister of Industry declared the company nationalised as from DATE .

CARDINAL . While LAW expressly provided for compensation , no such compensation was paid to the company 's owners . Under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) the Government were obliged to enact detailed rules governing compensation .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant 's step - uncle was convicted by the former ORG ( národní soud ) of committing offences under LAW no . CARDINAL on the Security of the Republic ( zákon na ochranu republiky ) and under Presidential Decree no . CARDINAL on the Punishment of NORP Criminals , Traitors and Their Collaborators and on ORG ( dekret prezidenta republiky o potrestání nacistických zločinců , zrádců a jejich pomahačů a o mimořádných lidových soudech ) and his property confiscated .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant applied under the Decree to ORG for compensation for the value of his shares in the company , together with other nationalised goods . No reply was given to him .

CARDINAL . On DATE GPE and GPE concluded an agreement providing for compensation to settle claims of NORP nationals arising from nationalisation measures in GPE . According to letters exchanged on this occasion between the contracting Governments the agreement did not apply to the applicant 's claim with regard to the company despite his NORP citizenship .

CARDINAL . NORP In DATE , after the collapse of the communist rule , the applicant visited former GPE and was assured by the new ORG that the past injustices towards him and his family would be remedied . The then Federal Deputy Prime Minister publicly stated in this respect :

“ The approach of the past regime to the PERSON family was based entirely on lies . It was based on the claim that [ the applicant 's step - uncle ] was a collaborator and that the heirs of [ the applicant 's father ] thus do not have any right to claim anything . We have to take a fair approach . It is necessary to apologise on behalf of the ORG and give the PERSON family full satisfaction and , furthermore , consider negotiations on damages . ”

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG and ORG refused the applicant 's claims for compensation , stating that the applicant 's step - uncle had been the true owner of the company . A similar letter was sent to the applicant by PERSON on DATE .
CARDINAL . The company went into liquidation on DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the liquidator wrote to ORG , seeking compensation for the company 's nationalised property under LAW . On DATE the Minister of ORG replied , inter alia , in the following terms :

“ A decision granting the required compensation for the nationalised property can not be issued due to the lack of necessary regulations ; in other words , the Government have not yet adopted the regulation as provided for in LAW of [ LAW ] . ... Admittedly , the claim for compensation came into existence by virtue of the [ Presidential Decree ] which provided in its LAW that compensation has to be paid for nationalised property ; however the right to such compensation can only be executed once the terms and conditions set forth in the decree are enacted . ”
CARDINAL . NORP The Minister further stated that no compensation could be provided to the applicant under the restitution legislation .
CARDINAL . On DATE , in reply to the liquidator 's subsequent letter CARDINAL DATE , the Minister stated in particular :

“ [ Your objections ] are not substantiated . The [ previous ] position adopted by ORG ... is in conformity with the legal opinion of ORG acting as an administrative court when dismissing an administrative action seeking the payment of compensation for nationalised property under the [ Presidential Decree ] . The court expressed the following opinion :

' ... the duty to issue a decision must be in conformity with procedural and substantive law . However , there is no substantive law on the basis of which a decision granting or rejecting a compensation claim for nationalised property could be based . From ORG decision ( e.g. Pl . ÚS CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) concerning the Presidential Decrees issued in DATE it appears that these Decrees continue to be part of the national legal system , but can not serve as a basis for taking decisions . In those circumstances , ORG is not competent to deliver any decision under Decree no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL . The mere existence of the adjective law , Act no . TIME [ LAW ] is not sufficient to create the power of the administrative authority to decide . ' ... ”

CARDINAL . In a letter of DATE sent to the applicant in the matter of his request for compensation under the Decree the Minister of Finance maintained that the applicant 's step - uncle had been the true owner of the company 's assets at the time of its nationalisation .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG quashed the judgment of ORG DATE by which the applicant 's step - uncle had been convicted , and remitted the case to the prosecutor for further consideration . Subsequently , on DATE , the prosecutor decided to discontinue these criminal proceedings .

CARDINAL . Pursuant to section DATE ) of the Decree enterprises for the production of leather , artificial leather , leather products and their substitutes with CARDINAL employees according to the average number of employees as of DATE and DATE were nationalised as from that date . The former ORG was authorised to declare which companies had been nationalised .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) excludes from the right to compensation various categories of people , including , for example , those who had supported the NORP occupation . None of these exceptions is relevant to the present case . Paragraph CARDINAL provides , inter alia , that if a legal entity is not paid compensation for its property , pro rata compensation is to be paid to the shareholders .
CARDINAL . In accordance with section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) compensation is to be provided for nationalised property .

CARDINAL . NORP Under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) the condition and liabilities of the nationalised property on DATE of its takeover by the national enterprise is decisive for the purpose of assessing compensation . The compensation was to be equal to the general price of the property calculated in accordance with official prices on DATE of nationalisation , or , should there be no such prices , prices ascertained by an official appraisal after deduction of liabilities . The Minister of Industry may , in agreement with the Minister of Finance , issue a regulation for assessment of the general price and evaluation of liabilities for the purposes of calculation of compensation in accordance with this provision .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) provides that compensation for nationalised property is provided ( a ) in the form of consideration similar to allowances from the national insurance system , ( b ) in the form of securities , ( c ) in cash or ( d ) in other assets . Under paragraph CARDINAL , the government shall adopt a regulation governing the provision of compensation pursuant to sub - paragraph ( a ) and shall lay down therein principles for providing compensation in cash and in other assets .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) establishes , in order to provide compensation , ORG , an independent legal entity with its registered office in GPE . Under paragraph CARDINAL , for the purposes of provision of the compensation in accordance with section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(b ) , the ORG shall issue bonds guaranteed by the ORG . They shall bear interest and be redeemed by the ORG . They may be used for money deposits of infants and wards . The Government shall regulate the interest - rates and the redemption by secondary legislation . Paragraph CARDINAL holds that the Government shall regulate the organisation , administration and management of the ORG by a regulation .

CARDINAL . Under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) the Minister of Finance , in agreement with the empowered minister , is to decide on the compensation and the manner of its provision . Under paragraph CARDINAL , the compensation is payable within DATE of the adoption of the decision . Under paragraph CARDINAL , the regulations on administrative procedure apply to compensation proceedings under LAW .

CARDINAL . Under LAW approves Presidential Decrees issued on the basis of LAW on LAW of DATE . All Presidential Decrees are to be regarded ab initio as laws and constitutional Presidential Decrees are to be regarded as constitutional laws .
CARDINAL . The Regulation was issued under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the LAW no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL on ORG .

CARDINAL . Under section CARDINAL(b ) ORG exercises , inter alia , compensatory services under the Decree as amended . Under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) expenditures from the ORG include a ) amounts destined to pay interest and redemption of securities which the ORG delivers by virtue of section PERSON ) of the Decree , to recover those securities , b ) compensatory payments in cash under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(b ) of the Decree , c ) charges to compensate in other assets within the meaning of section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(c ) of the Decree , d ) payments from ORG and e ) administrative fees of the compensatory services in accordance with the ORG budget .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) provides that from DATE ORG did not exercise the compensatory services which focused on concentration of means from enterprises and the ORG budget and financing of the enterprises . The Minister of Finance is charged with making adjustments to the organisation , administration and management of the Funds . Government Regulation no . CARDINAL ceased to be applicable on DATE on which this new regulation entered into force .
CARDINAL . In the preamble , ORG of the NORP and GPE affirmed its intention to redress the consequences of certain infringements of property and other rights which occurred DATE .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the LAW provides that its aim is to redress the consequences of certain violations of property and other rights caused by acts falling within the sphere of civil or labour law or by administrative acts incompatible with the principles of a democratic society respecting the rights of citizens , as enshrined in the LAW of ORG and LAW .

CARDINAL . According to sections CARDINAL ) and CARDINAL ) , such redress consists in the surrender of property if the violation in question was caused by an act infringing generally recognised human rights and freedoms , that is , an act in contradiction with the principles referred to in section CARDINAL ) of the LAW . When an entitled person was deprived of his or her property rights under nationalisation laws adopted DATE without appropriate compensation , the entitled person has a claim under this LAW , which he or she can raise under the particular law ( LAW ) .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) provides that , in order to be entitled to restitution of his or her property , a claimant must be a natural person and a citizen of the NORP and GPE whose property was ceded to the ORG in the circumstances listed in section CARDINAL of the Act . According to section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(e ) , if the person whose property has been transferred to the ORG in cases specified in section CARDINAL died before the expiry of the period specified in section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) , the entitled persons , provided they are citizens of the NORP and GPE , are his or her spouse and children , or in the case of the latter 's death , their children .

CARDINAL . Under LAW , a person who has unsuccessfully exhausted all the measures that a procedural regulation applicable to proceedings before administrative authorities sets out for his protection against the administrative authority 's failure to act , may , in its action , request the court to lay an obligation upon that authority to deliver a decision on the merits , or a certificate . Second paragraph provides that subject to complying with all other statutory requirements an action may be successful if the administrative authority failed to deliver a decision although it was obligated by law to deliver one .

CARDINAL . Under LAW the Government of GPE were to pay to ORG the sum of MONEY ( ORG ) in full and final settlement of NORP claims arising before DATE coming into force of that agreement against ORG and NORP natural and juridical persons in respect of property , rights and interests in GPE affected by NORP measures of nationalisation , expropriation , taking under administration or any other similar legislative or administrative measures .

CARDINAL . Article II ( CARDINAL ) specified that for the purpose of this Agreement “ NORP claims ” meant claims of natural persons who were NORP citizens on the date of the coming into force of this Agreement and who were or whose legal predecessors were NORP citizens on the date of the coming into force of the measures referred to in Article I or on the date on which the relevant measures were first applied to their property , rights or interests .
CARDINAL . ORG dismissed a constitutional appeal by Mr NORP NORP who had sought to have repealed Presidential Decree No . GPE . The court held , inter alia :

“ ... since the enemy occupation of NORP territory by the armed forces of the PERSON had made it impossible to assert the sovereign ORG power which stemmed from LAW of GPE , introduced by LAW no . CARDINAL , as well as from the whole NORP legal order , LAW , set up in GPE , must be regarded as the internationally recognised legitimate constitutional authority of the NORP State . In consequence thereof and as a result of their ratification by ORG . CARDINAL of DATE , all normative acts of LAW NORP ( NORP ) legislative power ... [ through which ] ... the constitutional and legal order of the Republic was achieved . ...

In view of the fact that [ the Decree ] has already accomplished its purposes and for a period of DATE has not created any further legal relations , so that it no longer has any constitutive character , its inconsistency with constitutional acts or international treaties ... can not , in the given situation , be reviewed DATE . ”
CARDINAL . ORG stated , inter alia :

“ The ORG did not adopt the opinion that all injustices would be redressed , but only some injustices , and to the extent and under the conditions stipulated by law . It was the ORG 's sovereign decision whether at all , and to what extent , property injustices would be redressed . ”
CARDINAL . ORG held , in particular :

“ [ T]he Act [ no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ] does not intend to provide redress for the consequences of all injustices , but to mitigate the consequences of only some injustices , not all of them . From that it follows that injustices other that those included in the LAW can not be rehabilitated , nor can they be rehabilitated in any way other than specified in the LAW ; ... From these statutory provisions [ section DATE ) and section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) second sentence of Act no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ] it can be deduced that if the legislator wanted to compensate also for the cases of confiscation for which compensation was to be provided , but had not been paid , it would have stipulated this explicitly in section DATE ) of the LAW , or within this LAW in another provision it would have extended the opportunity to mitigate the consequences of property and other injustices to include also the cases of confiscation for which compensation had not been provided , although it should have been . The legislator , however , did not do that . ”
CARDINAL . ORG held , in particular :

“ When formulating particular reasons for restitution , the legislator 's will have to be respected . If in section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) second line of the Extra - Judicial Rehabilitation Act , the restitution ground is formulated as following : ' When an entitled person was deprived of his or her property rights under nationalisation laws adopted DATE without appropriate compensation , the entitled person has a claim under this LAW , which he or she can raise under the particular legislation ' , regardless of the fact that the nationalisation took place ex lege [ ; ] the right to compensation must be applied and not eliminated . It is clear that in case of section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) second line of the Extra - Judicial Rehabilitation Act , the restitution ground is based on an act infringing generally recognised human rights [ section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(c ) of the Extra - Judicial Rehabilitation Act ] , not because of the act of nationalisation , but due to the failure to provide compensation which is the element of irregularity which constitutes an infringement of generally recognised human rights as provided for in LAW .

Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) second line of the Extra - Judicial Rehabilitation Act provides for a specific restitution ground not only because it is exercisable under the particular law which is LAW , but also because of the fact that the legislator 's will to redress those injustices which occurred in consequence of the nationalisation without compensation as required by section CARDINAL et seq . of Presidential Decree no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL has to be respected . ”

CARDINAL . In this judgment ORG expressed its opinion on the constitutionality of the specification of the decisive period in LAW . In its conclusions it referred to , inter alia , the opinion embodied in its judgment no . PERSON CARDINAL/CARDINAL , where it further held :

“ [ I]t is the ORG 's sovereign decision whether it allows restitution and to what extent property injustices are to be redressed . In ORG opinion , specifying the decisive period , and particularly its start date , as DATE , is based on rational and objective reasons , since the legislator was compelled to specify clearly a time threshold beyond which it is fundamentally impossible to go without the danger of causing compensations to build up to the time of the pre - GPE republic or even further into the past . ”

CARDINAL . The Constitutional Court further noted that in dealing with the issue of what method the NORP State would choose to redress property and other injustices that had occurred in the previous period in consequence of non - democratic acts of the previous regime , it chose a method based on the principle of at least a partial mitigation of injustices caused . The court held the following as regards the chosen concept :

“ [ F]rom many concepts the legislator has chosen , in the restitution regulations , the one that does not explicitly repeal the legal regulations on the basis of which the ownership was lost , but that [ instead ] presumes , to the contrary , that in separate proceedings it should be ascertained whether all requirements stipulated by the legislator in special restitution regulation for redressing property injustice are met . ”
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed a constitutional appeal against ORG failure to act upon a request to proceed under LAW . It held , inter alia :

“ At present , ORG is not authorised to act under Decree no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL . In ORG view that decree has already accomplished its purpose , since DATE it represents a closed group of problems and issues closely related to wartime events and the country 's economic recovery after the Second World War . For DATE it has not created any further legal relationships and it no longer has any constitutive character . Therefore , at present the respondent ORG is evidently not authorised to act pursuant to this Decree and thus it also can not decide on compensation for nationalised property under LAW seq . , regardless of the absence of an implementing regulation within the meaning of LAW , subsection CARDINAL of the Decree . ( ... ) ”
CARDINAL . ORG expressed its opinion on the concept of the restitution laws and the time - limits for the restitution claims , stating in particular :

“ The restitution laws enacted after DATE enshrine the legislator 's will to redress injustices that occurred DATE , that is . in the period defined in LAW no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL as the period of lack of freedom , in the period of a totalitarian system , and not any other injustices . The ORG 's will is clearly defined in the restitution laws themselves and redress is permissible only in the factual and time scope defined by these laws . ...

Should the time - limits set for the restitution claims be challenged , there would be no certainty or limit , be it factual or , and above all , time - limit , that would prevent former owners of property or their descendants from claiming property they had lost at any time in the past , even a very long time ago . ”
CARDINAL . In its opinion of CARDINAL DATE ORG plenary session stated , inter alia :

“ ( ... ) in its preamble LAW , which is the fundamental restitution law , explicitly excluded from restitution property which had passed to the ORG prior to the decisive date . Therefore , it is not true that the LAW does not deal with property other than property that passed to the ORG during the relevant period , but in fact it concerns all property that the ORG owned on DATE of the entry into force of the LAW ( DATE ) , and which it had acquired in the period prior to DATE . By excluding ... any redress for property injustices ' caused in periods even deeper in the past , including the injustices caused to citizens of NORP and NORP origin , the LAW provided that the ORG owned this property and that claims to it relying on the general laws could not be raised . ...

Although ORG established a tendency towards redressing injustices to the widest extent possible , it was always within the regulations passed with a view to mitigating the injustices which occurred DATE , ... and not other injustices . The ORG 's will is clearly defined by the restitution laws themselves and redress is permissible only to the factual and time extent defined by these laws . ...

To the question of whether it is possible to seek protection of an ownership right that ceased to exist prior to DATE applying the general civil law rather than by using the methods stipulated by the restitution regulations ... , ORG replies in the negative . ”
CARDINAL . ORG held , in particular :

“ The restitution laws provided redress for nationalisation of property – in the relevant period – carried out in conformity with the then valid law but without compensation . It was section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the Extra - Judicial Rehabilitation Act which , in regard of industrial enterprises , created a class of restitution beneficiaries whose claims were linked to privatisation settlement under LAW of LAW [ Act no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ] . Undoubtedly , the aim of this legislation was to distinguish , from the massive group of the then owners of nationalised enterprises , natural persons who would be empowered for redress of property injustices suffered .

However , no further extension of the claims of the owners of the nationalised enterprises was planned . [ T]he extensive interpretation used by the plaintiff also lacks constitutional conformity ( see the finding of the Plenary of ORG , no . PERSON . ÚS CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) . Still less could approximately assessed compensation , as calculated of course without foundation , by the plaintiff , be accepted . In other words , [ granting ] such a claim for compensation would in general terms lead to a blanket compensation of natural persons for property nationalised under decrees adopted in DATE , those persons being entitled to calculate arbitrary amounts to be paid . Such a procedure can not be permitted , as it contravenes not only ordinary law but is also unconstitutional ( see finding of ORG DATE , ORG no . I. ÚS CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) . ”
CARDINAL . ORG held , inter alia :

“ It is necessary to proceed in compliance with the principle of a broader application of fundamental rights and freedoms and to adopt an interpretation which observes the sense and substance of fundamental rights ... Any application or interpretation to the contrary would constitute a breach of LAW , under which the substance and sense of fundamental rights and freedoms must be observed in the course of the application of the provision specifying the restrictions imposed on them . Such restrictions may not be misused to serve any other purpose but those for which they were specified . ”

CARDINAL . ORG decided in this landmark ruling in favour of an action challenging inactivity on the part of ORG , which had failed to pursue administrative proceedings upon the introduction of a request for compensation under the Decree . While emphasising that its present ruling did not deal with the question as to whether compensation should be granted , the court found that the request had triggered administrative proceedings and accordingly ordered the Ministry to adopt a formal decision .
It held , inter alia :

“ [ The court ] did not accept ... the obiter dictum opinion briefly articulated in ORG decision no . II . ÚS CARDINAL/CARDINAL , in accordance with which a request for compensation pursuant to this legislation [ the Decree ] , which no longer gives rise to rights and obligations , does not trigger administrative proceedings . ”
